Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Opportunity for U/V band stellar imaging using intensity interferometry with the VERITAS Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interferometry is a method for combining the light from multiple telescopes to generate an image with exceptionally high spatial resolution. Such acuity cannot be obtained by either telescope alone. This challenging technique can resolve stars outside our solar system, despite their very great distances. Such a feat is impossible with any single telescope, for which even the closest stars are still seen as unresolved points of light. Ordinary interferometry combines the amplitudes of optical telescope signals to form an image. This project utilizes another kind of interferometry that makes use of the quantum nature of light (photons). This quantum approach was first demonstrated in the 1950?s. Kieda and collaborators update this approach by using large, well-separated optical light collectors and fast, modern electronics. They will form images of 35 bright stars over the course of a one-year observing campaign. They will use the VERITAS Observatory and their own dedicated detectors, electronics and data connectivity. This project will serve as a technology pathfinder that may lead to a new regime in ultra-high resolution optical astronomy.

This project will image stars in the UV/Optical bandpass using the method of Hanbury Brown Twiss (HBT) interferometry. This method utilizes the correlation between intensity fluctuations, also called photon bunching, that occurs when different detectors observe the same source. In this method, the intensity correlation time series is the interferometric quantity upon which images are derived. The main advantage of this method is that it is robust to atmospheric turbulence; however, its low inherent sensitivity demands large-area light collectors. It also requires fast time resolution and long integration times. Astronomical observations using HBT were done in the 1960?s and 1970?s during which time the angular diameters of more than 30 stars were measured with a resolution of 1 mas. This method was recently demonstrated on several bright stars with modern detectors and electronics operating in the photon-counting regime. Kieda and collaborators will use the VERITAS gamma-ray observatory telescopes to demonstrate imaging with intensity interferometry. They have validated key technologies for measuring spatial and temporal bunching of blackbody radiation. They have demonstrated the ability to reconstruct images using synthetic data. Their method requires sub-nanosecond synchronization of the data acquisition from multiple detectors spaced at ~100+ meter baselines. This project has the potential to demonstrate a scalable technology and open a wide, unexplored frontier for astronomical, optical imaging with ultra-high resolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tested the possibility of using an existing astronomical observatory for making ultra-high resolution measurements of stars. The project took advantage of an opportunity to instrument the VERITAS gamma-ray observatory with high-speed light sensors and electronics that could demonstrate the measurement of a star?s diameter in visible light. This grant purchased light sensors, electronic instrumentation, computer hardware, and fiber optic systems for VERITAS telescope to allow measurement of high-speed correlations in the light arriving from individual stars, and from this information, the diameter of the star was determined. The VERITAS Intensity Interferometry observatory performed measurement of the diameters of several bright stars during 2019.  From the measurements of the correlated visible light, the ability to measure the sub-milliarcsecond diameters of the stars was demonstrated. The diameters of these stars were determined with an accuracy of 5-10%.

 The award provided the research instrumentation necessary to demonstrate the validity of this new observation technique. The `intensity interferometry? technique demonstrated the measurement of stars in the visible light with a resolving power equivalent to a ~100-meter diameter telescope, but at fraction of the cost of a conventional optical telescope. The VERITAS intensity interferometric telescopes were able to perform these measurements while being connected with simple commercial fiber optic digital data transmission lines. This capability means that the technique is easily scalable to any desired telescope arrangement or separation, up to a communication-imposed limit of 80 km.  The instrumentation demonstrated the ability to measure the light intensity correlations between many independent telescopes simultaneously. The multi-telescope measurement capability demonstrates the key technology necessary for building a large (several kilometers baseline) array of 50-100 optical telescopes.  Such an array would have the ability to reconstruct an image of a distant star in visible light. The array would have angular resolution better than 40 nano-arcseconds, making it the highest angular resolution observatory in the world.  Such a telescope array could be used to take a sequence of visible images of binary stars, and use the sequence to generate a movie of their mutual orbit, and study their interactions. This technology can also be used to build a large array of movable telescopes. This array of movable telescopes could be mounted on a system of rails (such as the VLA radio array, or the ALMA submillimeter array in Chile) and could reconfigured to optimize the visible band imaging resolution and the field of view of an observation to match the size of a particular star or binary system.

The instrumentation developed and commissioned by this award is now being used by the VERITAS Observatory in an observation campaign to catalog the diameters of 30 bright stars during the next 18 months. We expect the observing campaign will also develop the imaging capabilities of the technique, and it will establish a database of intensity interferometric observations in the visible band that, when complete, will be distributed online and made freely available to researchers worldwide. The dataset will allow astronomers to develop image reconstruction algorithms for the reconstruction of the stellar images of the stars in the catalog.

 This award provided funding support for a PhD graduate student at the University of Utah (Nolan Matthews) as well as supporting three undergraduate students to assist with the development of the hardware and software, and perform observations.
